comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Funnily enough a quieter room than the reading room.  The prices are almost certainly in £sd and d's rather than s's in an army mess.  These would probably have been snacks and optional extras as the soldiers would have been on rations which they would have eaten in one of the dining rooms in the Curragh Camp.  No mention of time NLI or did the clock escape your eagle eye on this occasion???  14,00 hours I make it?  What is the dapper civilian doing in the other ranks coffee room?

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Those prices would be in pence, as in £-s-d. Presumably, the cost of eating in their canteen was subsidised?

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: From my days in uniform I remember there was all ways  somewhere other ranks could purchase extra food , drinks/tobacoo products etc. after their daily duties,usually subsidised.So I bet those prices are in pence. The 16th July 1916 being a Sunday would explain why these privates are present in the middle of the afternoon.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Did spot the time, but didn't want to inflict my obsession on ye all!  :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] Thanks for reminding me about the Sunday thing. I've decided from now on to always add the day of the week to the Date part of each photo's description, and to tag the day as well. (Will have to do some retrofitting!) That way we can all search for photos on here by day as well as date, and who knows, the data could be useful...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Glad you all seem to think the prices were in d or pennies - that's what I thought too. Fascinating to know what they ate and how much they had to pay for it... Any ideas on what the metal box contraption is that's perched on the counter?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: It looks like a donation box of some sort.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I thought it might be one of those magic lantern boxes or a Zoetrope, but I don't see any slides or pictures inside. Looks like an opening at top and the money slides down the incline to the glass box below. Maybe it's the cash register? Money goes in the top, goes down to the bottom; hard to fish the change out with the slanted tray like that?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I think it's a patent "Woodbine" dispenser.  You can see the cup for the tuppence on top and the slot for the 5 woodbine at the bottom.  What you can't see is the handle at the other side to free up the 5 fags!  If you wanted any further confirmation that it was July and not January see the open roof lights for ventilation in this!

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: These boxes are a dead ringer of a similar device used on the buses here in Toronto.You deposit your coins in the top slot and it drops into the glassed area and is checked by the fare  collector,if it is correct they push a lever releasing the coins into the locked box below.Which will be collected at the end of the shift.This keeps everybody honest and prevents "skimming". The downside is you need exact change.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So, the money would go in the curvy part [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] and either it was a form of cash register [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] or a cigarette dispenser [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] ...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: I like [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie/]'s cigarette theory It's what's missing. Soldiers and coffee and no cigarettes? consider these near contemporaries: idisk.mac.com/smallvintagevending/Public/website/third/cr... idisk.mac.com/smallvintagevending/Public/website/third/j_... www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=6589 www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=4685 Except . . . the first cigarette vending machine is thought to have been invented in 1926 by William Rowe. Maybe that was just the first to sell by the pack?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Also like the cigarette theory proposed by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie]. However if specifically cigarette machines weren't invented until 1926, that can't be...

I'm wondering if it might have been a vending machine for postage stamps, that had been on the go since the 19th century. I know it might be an odd location for it, slap bang in the middle of the serving counter, but if you examine the cabinet at the end of the counter, you'll see postcards, etc. Also, I think there's a large weighing machine lurking between the doors at the back or the Coffee Room. Would the soldiers weigh parcels there, and then get stamps at the counter??

P.S. Thanks for searching out the gorgeous array of vending machines!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: The Curragh Camp had it's own Post Office so I doubt that it was necessary to weigh parcels in the canteen.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] Damn! Still might be a stamp machine though, and I'm still convinced that's a weighing machine lurking between the doors. Do not laugh, but could it have been for the men? Soldiers, physical fitness and all that?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77338355@N06
comment._content: This is the dining room of Miss Sandes Soldiers Home in the Curragh - one of over thirty such Homes attached to army locations all over Ireland, Founded by Elise Sandes of Tralee, Co Kerry, this network of Soldiers Homes was an evangelical missionary movement designed mainly to keep young soldiers out of the pubs and provide recreational facilities - as well as a bit of religion. The first Home was in Cork and later ones were in Queesntown (Cobh), Belfast, Parkgates Dublin, Ballykinler, Derry, among other towns; there were eight Homes in India in places such as Rawal Pindi, Quetta and Lucknow. See www.historyireland.com/volumes/volume13/issue4/news/?id=1...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77338355@N06] Thanks again! Have added your information into the description above...  :)

comment.author: 78620024@N07
comment._content: You could add another 50 years to this 1916 photo and little had changed.The long benches and tables were still the same.They did add a jukebox in the early 60s.It was in front of the pillar were that first soldier is standing .A record could be played for 3d.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78620024@N07] Delighted with your information! Absolutely nothing can beat an eye witness account. I've added your comment to the description under the photo itself... Thank you! And do you remember the Reading Room?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
